ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

TEACHER TRAINING IN 1968
(Number of applicants accepted and rejected)


    1. Mr L. P. Rodrigo asked the Minister for Education (a) how many persons applied for Teacher Training in 1968, and how many were accepted and how many rejected; and (b) what were the qualifications of those who were selected and those rejected.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Dr Lee Chiaw Meng) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, there were 5,547 applicants for 793 vacancies in teacher training. Seven hundred and fifty one appointments were made and 4,796 applicants were rejected. The number of appointments was slightly smaller than the number of vacancies because some graduate vacancies were left unfilled for lack of suitable applicants and a few selected candidates with School Certificate and Higher School Certificate qualifications declined appointment at the last minute.

    As for the second part of the question, all the selected candidates satisfied the age and citizenship requirements and the great majority possessed educational qualifications higher than the minimum requirements which are specified in the recruitment advertisement and vary according to the type of training and the language medium. Some of the un successful candidates were rejected because they did not satisfy the age and citizenship requirements. Others were rejected owing to the limited number of vacancies in the particular type of training for which they were eligible.

    Mr L. P. Rodrigo (Serangoon Gardens): Sir, can the Parliamentary Secretary inform the House how many of those rejected were in possession of the minimal required qualifications?

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Sir, the majority of those rejected had the minimum qualifications, but, off- hand, I cannot give the exact figure. If the

hon. Member so desires, he can give notice of another question.

TEACHER EDUCATION
(Adjustments or changes)


    2. Mr L. P. Rodrigo asked the Minister for Education what adjustments or changes have been made in teacher education to meet the needs of the country at this stage of its development.

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, major adjustments and changes have been made in teacher education to meet the relevant needs of the Republic.

    With the emphasis on technical education, the training of technical teachers has been greatly stepped up at the Teachers' Training College. At present, the College is conducting three special technical courses in addition to the normal technical ones. The special courses are the industrial arts course, a crash craft teacher training programme for holders of the School Certificate and the Higher School Certificate. The third course is for the re- training of non-technical qualified teachers in metalwork, woodwork and basic electricity.

    To meet the shortage of technical teachers, student- teachers who joined the first year part-time general course were encouraged to opt for the technical course.

    Several in-service courses, both professional and non-professional, are being conducted and planned to promote professionalism within the teaching profession and also to inculcate greater awareness of the political, economic and social changes in the Republic. These courses have been designed as part of the general further teacher education programme.

    Emphasis has also been laid on courses conducted in the teaching of English and Chinese as second languages.

Column: 115

NANYANG UNIVERSITY
(Honours degree courses)


    3. Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon asked the Minister for Education, since the Nanyang University degrees are recognised by the Government and some Departments of the University are adequately staffed and equipped, if he will ask the Council of the University to look into the possibility of the University offering honours degree courses as from the next academic year.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is learnt from the Nanyang University authorities that the University proposes to introduce, as from the next academic session, honours degree courses in a number of departments that are well staffed and equipped. It is also learnt that those departments which are not yet ready to offer honours degree courses will do so as and when staff and facilities have reached a comparable standard.

Column: 115

NANYANG UNIVERSITY
GRADUATES
(Admission to higher degree courses at University of Singapore)


    4. Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon asked the Minister for Education if he will as-certain from the University of Singapore authorities whether consideration has been given to the admission of Nan-yang University graduates to higher degree courses at the University of Singapore.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the University of Singapore now admits Nanyang University graduates as candidates for Master's degrees. Generally, for admission as a candidate for a Master's degree, a person must be a graduate of the University of Singapore or a graduate of such other university as the Senate may approve, and must have obtained a degree with honours and must submit evidence of adequate training and ability to under-lake the proposed course.

Column: 116



    However, exceptions are made for graduates of universities which do not award degrees with honours. Graduates of such universities, including Nanyang University, can therefore be considered for admission as Master's candidates provided the Faculties concerned are of the view that they are of exceptional merit. They must take a qualifying examination of a standard equivalent to that of the University's own honours examination. If the Senate is assured by the Faculties concerned that the candidates have reached the honours level in the qualifying examination, it will then consider their admission as Master's candidates in the normal manner.

    The University of Singapore has admitted two Nanyang University B.A, graduates to the Master's courses in Arts. Five Nanyang University B.Sc, graduates who have obtained the Diploma in Fisheries from the University of Singapore have also been admitted as Master of Science candidates doing research in the field of fishing.

SCHOLARSHIPS FOR TECHNICAL
EDUCATION
(Number to be offered to teachers and University students in 1969)


    5. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Education, in view of the Government's policy of encouraging technical education, how many scholar ships in this field will be offered in 1969 to (a) University students, and (b) teachers.

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng (for the Minister for Education)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not possible at this juncture to state how many awards in the field of technical education will be offered in 1969 to university students and teachers as the 1969 Budget proposals have yet to be passed by Parliament.

    Awards made this year are generally renewed next year subject to satisfactory progress and conduct, while fresh awards would largely depend on the

Column: 117

availability of suitable applicants to meet the needs of industry and institutions in both the public and private sectors.

    A greater allocation of the voted provisions will most assuredly be made to those who take courses of study that will enable them to contribute a useful role to society on graduation.

    The following information will, however, indicate the encouragement given in the field of technical education.

(a) University students

    Out of a total of 87 new awards which included scholarships, bursaries and study loans made this year for the 1968/69 session, 84 awards were for students in the Singapore Polytechnic and three for students in Ngee Ann College. Of the awards for students in the Singapore Polytechnic, four awards were for professional courses, 29 awards were for degree courses and 51 were for technician courses. The three awards for students in Ngee Ann College were for Mechanical Engineering. In addition to these awards, there were 60 new awards for overseas training under various technical assistance schemes in Australia, Canada, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, Japan, Germany and France.

    A total number of 131 scholarships and bursaries were renewed for students in the Singapore Polytechnic and Ngee Ann College this year. Of this total number of renewals, 128 were for students in the Singapore Polytechnic and three for students in Ngee Ann College.

(b) Teachers

    As for scholarships to teachers in technical education, the Government has already approved a total of 28 awards for training overseas in 1969 under various schemes such as the Colombo Plan, the Commonwealth Teacher Training Bursary and the United Nations Development Programme. Such training covers a wide range of technical subjects in fields like machine shop and fitting, motor vehicles, welding and sheet metal,

Column: 118

electrical installation and maintenance, shipbuilding and drafting, building, woodworking, trade skill testing and trade standard, wood carving, modelling and sculpture, in Australia, Canada, India, the United Kingdom, France and Italy.

    Fifty-six bursaries were awarded this year to technical student teachers at the Teachers' Training College. For next year provision has been requested for 150 fresh awards for full-time technical teacher training.

ON-THE-JOB TRAINING IN
INDUSTRIES
(Legislation for compulsory intake of students)


    6. Mr Low Guan Onn asked the Minister for Education, in view of the reluctance and unco- operative attitude of employers to offer on-the-job training opportunities for short periods of time to students of Vocational Institutes, the Polytechnic and the Universities, if the Government will consider introducing legislation to make it compulsory for industries to take in a quota of students for such training each year.

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry is aware that active participation of industry at various levels in some form of in-plant training scheme is essential. We do get the co-operation of some industrial establishments in providing short-term training, conducted within the institutional training period during vacation.

    As industry in Singapore is now undergoing development and expansion, many d~ not have the necessary supervisors and industrial training officers to organise effective on-the-job training programmes.

    With a greater output of vocational-technical graduates from our institutions by 1970, the question of promoting this facet of technical education by suitable legislative measures or fiscal relief may be considered, if co-operation from industry is still not adequately forthcoming by then.

Column: 119



    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim (Kallang): Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Parliamentary Secretary consider measures to see that apprentices and trainees are not exploited as cheap labour if legislation is introduced?

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Sir, I assure the hon. Member for Kallang that we will consider this matter very carefully.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Sir, does the Parliamentary Secretary not consider the reluctance and unco- operative attitude of certain employers selfish and shortsighted and not conducive to the national interest in economic development?

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I will say "reluctance" but not "unco-operative". The reluctance of employers is due more to the lack of personnel to conduct these courses. For such courses to be effective, there must be suitable and adequate supervisory personnel. At this stage of development and industrialisation, most of the industries, I am afraid, are not adequately equipped with such personnel.

Column: 119

RADIO AND TELEVISION COURSE
ON ENGINEERING SCIENCE


    7. Mr Low Guan Onn asked the Minister for Education, with the emphasis now on technical education, if the Government will consider conducting a weekend radio and television course on the basic theory of engineering science for the benefit of those workers in industries who have the practical skills but lack theoretical knowledge, as such knowledge will upgrade the quality of their skills and improve the standard of goods produced.

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, the possibility of using the television medium as an extension of the vocational and technical education programme is being considered by the Ministry. The basic theory of engineering science for workers in industries is also included in this study. A preliminary survey shows that such programmes could be mounted

Column: 120

provided adequate staff and finance could be made available.

    Mr Rodrigo: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Parliamentary Secretary referring to Educational Television Service or the ordinary television broadcasts of T.V. Singapura?

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Sir, I am referring to Educational Television.

PRIMARY SCHOOL ENROLMENT OF CHILDREN NEAR THEIR
HOMES


    8. Mr P. Selvadurai asked the Minister for Education if he will take steps that will result in primary school children not being enrolled in schools many miles away from the areas in which they live.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, during the registration exercise carried out in July this year, a total of 55,526 children were'-registered for admission to Primary I in 1969. Of this number, 51,242 or 92.3 per cent of these children will be admitted to schools of their parents' choice and only 4,284 or 7.7 per cent need be posted to schools other than of their parents' choice, because such children were registered in excess of the maximum intake of the schools con cerned. All the 4,284 children registered in excess have already been posted to schools which have vacancies near their homes.

TIONG BAHRU CONSTITUENCY
(Building of more schools)


    9. Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon asked the Minister for Education, as there are only two primary schools, one Chinese and the other English, in the Tiong Bahru. Constituency, and in view of the development of more Housing and Development Board housing estates in that constituency, if his Ministry plans to build more schools in that Constituency what are the types of schools that will be built, and when they will be built.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no plan to build any primary school in the Tiong Bahru Constituency.

GOVERNMENT AND
GOVERNMENT-AIDED SCHOOLS
(Particulars of schools and specialist teachers and principle on staffing)


    10. Mr L. P. Rodrigo asked the Minister for Education (a) what are the various official types of Government and Government-aided schools to date; (b) what are the different official kinds of specialist teachers on the staffs in those schools today, that is, the specialist teachers as distinct from the general teachers like the Normal Trained and Certificate in Education teachers; and (c) what is the principle governing the current staffing of such schools.

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, to date, there are the following official types of schools: 

  Government Schools

       Primary schools

       Primary cum Vocational schools

       Secondary schools

       Secondary Technical schools

       Secondary Vocational schools.


    With effect from January 1969 there will be only three official types: 

      Primary schools

      Secondary schools

      Secondary Technical schools



  Government-aided schools

       Primary schools

       Secondary schools

       Full schools (i.e. schools with both 

            primary and secondary classes.)

       Trade school.


    As to the second part of the question, Sir, there are three official types of specialist teachers on the staff of Government and Government-aided schools (full and secondary schools), namely:

    (a) Grade I (drawing allowance of $240 p.m.)

    (b) Grade II (drawing allowance of $180 p.m.)

Column: 122



    (c) Grade III (drawing allowance of $120 p.m.).

    As to the third part of the question, Sir, the principle governing the current staffing of such schools is to ensure that schools are adequately staffed with teachers to teach the subjects on the curriculum at primary and secondary levels. Special care is taken to see that adequate provision is given for teaching second languages, technical and voca tional subjects including domestic science. The governing principle bears close relation to the number of classes in a school, the level of instruction, and the type of subjects, whether second language, technical or vocational.

    Mr Rodrigo: Mr Speaker, Sir, I take it that these specialist teachers will be undertaking the teaching of special subjects and that, apart from them, there will be the category of general teachers who will be expected to undertake the teaching of any subject assigned to them by the principal of the school.

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Mr Speaker, Sir, according to the scheme of educa-~ tional service, a specialist teacher is one who is employed to teach such subjects as English, Mathematics, Science, Geography and History at Secondary 111 and higher levels. This, is a dying category and no new appointments have been made in this grade since January 1968.

EXEMPTION OF SCHOOL FEES IN 1968 AND
AWARDS OF SCHOLAR-SHIPS AND BURSARIES
(Particulars)


    11. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Education (a) how many Secondary IV and pre-University students have been exempted from pay-ing school fees in 1968; and (h) how many students in the University of Singapore, Nanyang University, Singa-, pore Polytechnic and Ngee Ann College are scholarship or bursary holders, and' if he will give details of the various scholarships and bursaries awarded.

Column: 123



    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng (for the Minister for Education)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, 7,389 Secondary IV and 1,240 pre- University students have been exempted from paying school fees in 1968. But I would like to stress this point. Although the other students are paying their school fees, the Government has to subsidise every secondary school student to the extent of about $300 each year.

    Thirty-three scholarships and 759 bursaries were awarded and 147 study loans were made to a total of 939 students in the University of Singapore, Nanyang University, the Singapore Polytechnic and Ngee Ann College in 1968. I would also like to point out that although these students are paying from $450 to $540 on fees, each student in these institutions of higher learning is subsidised by Government by a sum varying from $2,000 to $7,000. In fact the fees paid by these students is negligible.

    There are two types of scholarship open to Singapore citizens pursuing higher studies. They are the President's Scholarships valued at $3,000 per annum and the Merit Scholarships valued at $2,400 per annum. Both are awarded on the basis of academic 'excellence in the Higher School Certificate examination and outstanding performance in extra-curricular acti vities.

    The Merit bursaries valued at $1,500 per annum for degree courses and $1,000 per annum for technician courses are also awarded on the basis of merit alone, irrespective of financial circumstances.

    Special bursaries are set aside for Malays who gain entry to any institution of higher learning and who qualify for assistance on financial grounds. The amount of such bursaries varies according to the need.

    All scholarship and bursary holders are bonded to serve the Government on completion of their studies.

    For those who are unable to get a scholarship or a bursary, interest-free study loans of the same amount as

Column: 124

bursary awards are available. Students who obtain such loans are not bonded to serve the Government but are required to repay their loans by instalments within three years of completing their studies.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Sir, this kind of policy should be praised and commended, but can the Parliamentary Secretary assure us that this same policy will be pursued next year?

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng(In Mandarin): Sir, we review our policy every year but I do not anticipate major changes.

SCHOOL TREE-PLANTING AND
GARDENING COMPETITION
(Particulars of expenditure)


    12. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Education (a) how much was spent by each school for the recent tree-planting and gardening competition; (b) from what source was the expenditure met; and (c) what percentage per school of the expenditure came from the school's miscellaneous fund.

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng (for the Minister for Education)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the three questions can be conveniently answered together. For the Tree-Planting Campaign and Competition, the Ministry of Education authorised principals of schools the use of the Sports Fund, Science Fund and Miscellaneous Fund. Restrictions, how ever, were placed on the use of such funds. Utilisation of the Sports Fund was restricted to purchase of top soil, fertilisers and sludge and for the transportation of sludge; utilisation of the Science Fund was restricted to purchase of tree saplings and rooted or unrooted cuttings for potted plants which could not be obtained free of charge from the Botanic Gardens and the Woodleigh Nursery; and the utilisation of the Miscellaneous Fund was limited to a maximum of $200 for the purchase of materials such as tree-guards, pots and bricks which could not be obtained from the Central Supplies Office.

Column: 125



    The amount spent by schools ranged from approximately $50 to $200. This variation in the total expenditure and also the variation of expenditure from the Miscellaneous Fund were due to differences between schools in available resources and facilities and in the sizes 'of school grounds.

    In the campaign and competition some schools were fortunate enough to obtain voluntary contributions of potted plants, saplings and bricks from teachers, parents, old boys and well-wishers, through the assistance of School Advisory Committees, Parent / Teacher Associations and Old Boys' Associations.

    Mr Tay Boon Too (Paya Lebar)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Parliamentary Secretary say what action will be taken against a school which used money in excess of the $200?

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng(In Mandarin): Sir, if there is such a case, we shall investigate it first and ascertain the circumstances in which the excess money came to be used. If it should transpire that as a result of investigation further action is necessary the case will be looked into further.

NATIONAL MUSEUM
(Better utilisation of facilities by schools for educational purposes)


    13. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Education what relationship exists between schools and the National Museum; and if his Ministry will con sider arrangements with the appropriate authority for the better utilisation of the facilities of the Museum by schools for educational purposes, such as lecture-tours of the Museum for students, etc.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, liaison between schools and the National Museum with regard to the better utilisation of museum facilities has not been adequately established, as the National Museum is not as yet in a position to provide a proper museum

Column: 126

school service to cope with the increasing interest and requests from schools.

    The Ministry of Education is considering arrangements with the appropriate authorities for the provision, of a museum school service. The organisa tion of such a service will depend upon the secondment of suitable teachers to the National Museum as museum education officers. New posts will have to be created in the National Museum's establishment so that the secondment of teachers can be effected.

    It will take some time for all these establishment problems to be sorted out, although in principle the idea of organising a school museum service has been - acceptable as a very desirable educational development.

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for resumption of debate on Question [3rd December, 1968], "That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st January, 1969 to 31st March, 1970." - [The Minister for Finance].

    Question again proposed.

3.02p.m.

    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise in admiration, but not wholly in support, of the business-like Budget that has been forcefully and persuasively presented by the Minister for Finance. The Budget, as I see it, can be divided into two parts. One deals with the need for an increase in the Government's revenue. The other spells out the precise manner in which the increase may be effected.

    There is no denying the validity of the Minister's contention that with Singapore assuming the responsibility for its own security and defence, it is necessary to find funds to train our citizens and equip them with the military hardware for our own defence. That is, as the Minister has pointed out, defence in the event of limited warfare - not warfare involving the

Column: 127

super-powers. A convincing case has been made out for such realistically qualified defence of our Republic.

    It follows logically that new taxes have .to be imposed to make possible such defence. A snag here is that taxation does not seem to be conducive to the promotion of industrial development. The difficulty has been overcome, however, by adopting a policy of indirect taxation which is to be borne by those sufficiently affluent to bear it. The general impression seems to be that the Budget is as fair as can be in the circumstances. But I prefer to leave it to those Members in this House who represent the interests of the employers to point out in detail how the Budget is not expected to have any disincentive effect on the economy.

    For my part, I prefer to touch on the disincentive effect of the Budget on the workers of Singapore. It is with some temerity that I attempt to point out such disincentive effect, as the Minister has thrown out a challenge to us to say that the proposals contained in the Budget are not necessary or correct. It is my intention, however, to try to avoid the challenge by restricting myself to pointing out the omission from the Budget of proposals that seem equally necessary and correct to me.

    I am concerned with the effect of, for instance, the imposition of 15 per cent tax on made-up garments which include underwear. Two reasons have, been advanced for such a tax. One is that it helps to promote our local industries. The other is that those who prefer imported foreign goods can very well pay for their preference. Granted that the reasons are valid, I do not think the duty of the Government should end with the imposition of tax alone. The reason why local consumers prefer to pay more for foreign goods than for the locally manufactured equivalent is simply that the former is far superior in quality. That being the reason, there seems hardly any justification that the taxpayer should in-

Column: 128

directly continue to subsidise our local manufacturers who have been accorded enough privileges or incentives to make' the other citizens appear to be second-class, as it were. The need for some sort of quality control of locally manufactured goods seems reasonable before the Government starts penalising local consumers for alleged bias against local goods.

    In conjunction with quality control, it seems equally reasonable that there' should be some sort of retail price control or restriction The Government has not been averse to enacting legislation to curb fringe benefits obtainable by our workers. But when it comes to' enacting legislation to restrain the greed of our domestic breed of entrepreneurs, the Government seems to drag its feet. Yet time and time again, it has been observed that the increase in the retail price of any goods on which a tax is imposed is more than proportionate to-the amount of the tax. To illustrate this point from my actual experience, I inquired about the price of a certain imported brand of briefs and singlets the day after the publication of the' Budget, and I was not surprised to find that the price had increased from $1.20 to $1.60 a piece, representing a jump of 33 1/3 per cent. If I have to pay this 33 1/3 per cent increase, I would rather that it goes into the Government revenue to be utilised for the general benefit of all than for the particular enrichment of a few. The insult to injury is compounded when it is realised that if the Government were to' rescind the 15 per cent tax next year, the price of the brand of underwear to which I have referred would be decreased by not more than ten per cent, if at all. This is borne out by our sad experience after the devaluation of the sterling in November 1967. The Prime Minister optimistically affirmed that by maintaining the parity of the Singapore dollar the workers of Singapore were given, in effect, a 14 per cent increase in wages. It would be interesting to know how many imported British goods had their prices reduced
